author: hendrik_h
content: Has anyone in here looked into the impact of same-fee "backrunning" transactions on the gas market?

author: sky.cactus
content: I haven't, but it is a bit wasteful because you end up with competing participants hash grinding and submitting many transactions.

author: hendrik_h
content: <@!301186049323958275> do you really end up hash grinding? At least geth should sort same-fee txs randomly (since they're stored in a map) so it should be an extremely inefficient numbers game?

author: hendrik_h
content: I agree it's wasteful, Wouldn't it be smarter to make the clients sort txs by hash to shift the workload from on-chain to the participants thereby reducing the amount of spam on-chain?

author: sky.cactus
content:
> geth should sort same-fee txs randomly (since they're stored in a map)
<@132827600492953600> This isn't actually random.  ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: It is deterministic, but follows an internal algorithm that is subject to change between versions of Go and is incredibly obscure.

author: sky.cactus
content: The "hash" you grind is the key in that map that "sorts" higher when the map is iterated.

author: sky.cactus
content: So what you do is submit a transaction, then grind transaction hashes or accounts (I forget which, been a while since I looked) until you get a better position in the map iteration and you submit that.  Repeat over and over until someone gets mined.

author: sky.cactus
content: It would be *nice* if the various clients did price-time priority, so the first transaction into the global pending pool with the same price gets in.  This isn't "fair" in the modern form of the word, but it at least doesn't result in network spam.

author: hendrik_h
content: <@!301186049323958275> Interesting! However the current makemap implementation (in the go runtime) uses a random hash seed (git blame shows this was last changed 3y ago). I just ran a couple of tests just to make sure the actual iterator logic is not doing any magic and could not reproduce your findings in the latest go version.

author: hendrik_h
content:
Still that does not change the fact that the bots using this strategy are currently taking ~6 spots in this months TOP25 gas consumers (and potentially even more if we sorted by #).
I'll do some more digging to figure out the real impact but I suspect that they do have an increasing influence on chain congestion. My current measurements show situations with over 1000 txs being spammed on a single trading opportunity.

So to stay on-topic it'd be great to run some more numbers here and include this load pattern in 1559 simulations.

author: sky.cactus
content: Hmm, have a link to the random hash bit of makemap?  As far as runtimes go, it seems outright silly to go out of your way to randomize the order of a hashmap.

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe I was thinking of Open Ethereum, or maybe I was just wrong.  ðŸ™‚
